Package mx.org.pescadormvp.core

Pescador MVP

Pescador MVP is a modular MVP framework for GWT that builds on standard MVP-related classes provided by GWT. Its features include GIN-based dependency injection and the association of places, activities, views, UI regions and components using generics.

The following is an overview of Pescador MVP and how to use it. For more details and examples, please see the walk-through of the sample application.

Contents:

  1. Components
  2. Place-Activity-View Components
  3. Activating Components and Starting the Framework
  4. Places
  5. Layout
  6. Activities and Views Not Associated with a Place
  7. Session
  8. Extras
    1. Caching Command-Pattern Data Manager
    2. Internal Links
    3. Logger

Components

At its core, Pescador MVP is a set of conventions for organizing your code, plus some classes that help you work with those conventions.

A central concept of Pescador MVP is the component. A component is a collection of related classes, including a class that implements Component and provides an interface for any external services that the component may offer to other components. The class that implements Component also performs tasks of general interest to the component. In addition, components provide a GinModule that sets GIN bindings for all the classes in the component.

Normally, all the classes in a component reside in the same package, or at least have a common ancestor package that is not shared with other components.

To use the MVP pattern, you designate certain components as "place-activity-view components". These special components associate a place class with one or more activity classes, view classes, and regions of the UI. They also include a class that implements PAVComponent (a subinterface of Component). Pescador MVP and GWT take care of activating activities and views in the right place at the right time. If you need to share implementations and specifications across places, activities, views and UI regions, you can use standard Java inheritance and polymorphism. (See below for more on place-activity-view components.)

In its present form, Pescador MVP does not:

  • enforce most conventions;
  • enforce encapsulation;
  • provide a way to specify dependencies among components;
  • provide a way to group components into larger units;
  • have fancy code generation to save you from reams of boilerplate; or
  • allow hot-swapping of components at runtime.

It is conceivable that these features (excluding the last one) might be implemented some time in the future. But even without them, Pescador MVP can help keep your client codebase nice and clean. (At least, that has been the author's experience.)

Place-Activity-View Components

Place-activity-view (PAV) components associate a place class with activity classes, view classes and regions of the UI. They do this through GIN, generics and tag interfaces that designate UI regions.

The easiest way to understand this is by looking at an example. A peek at QueryComponentImpl and the classes and interfaces in ...examples.jsonp.client.query will give you a good idea of how PAV components work. (See ...examples.jsonp.client for a step-by-step guide to this example. The following is just a brief summary.)

As you can see in ...examples.jsonp.client.query, the single activity has an interface and an implementation. The interface extends PescadorMVPPlaceActivity and the implementation is a subclass of PescadorMVPPlaceActivityBase . This superclass provides methods for the activity to retrieve the correct view and place instances when it starts. Note that there are interfaces and/or abstract superclasses for the view and place, too.

To see how bindings are set up for classes in this component, look at the component's GinModule, QueryGinModule.

This PAV component has only one activity class and only one view class because, in this simple example, there is only one UI region (designated with Layout.Body). For each PAV component (and so for each place) there can be as many activity-view pairs as there are UI regions. So in the example, if there were more UI regions, there could be more activity-view pairs.

To create your own PAV components, just copy the general pattern in the example, then activate your components and start up the framework as explained below, and you should be set. Behind the scenes, Pescador MVP activates the standard GWT PlaceController, PlaceHistoryHandler and ActivityManagers as required.

Testing is facilitated through dependency injection and the avoidance of references to implementations, as shown in the example. Incidentally, the example also shows how to use Jukito for pure Java tests and GWTTestCases for tests that require a browser context. (See the source code under examples/jsonp/src/test/java.)

Activating Components and Starting the Framework

In Pescador MVP, you control the global configuration of your application by creating a class that extends GlobalSetup (in the example app, ActiveGlobalSetup). Inside this class you define an interface that extends PescadorMVPGinjector (which itself extends Ginjector) and has a GinModules annotation. You use the annotation to declare all the GinModules you'll activate in your application, including, of course, those provided by your components.

In the constructor of your GlobalSetup subclass, you must send the superclass a list of the components you want to activate.

Framework initialization works like this: GlobalSetup has a static method that you use to pass in your Ginjector and start everything up. You can call this method directly from your GWT entry point method. Or, you can do so from a static method in your subclass of GlobalSetup, and call that static method from the GWT entry point. (See ActiveGlobalSetup and JSONPExample in the example app. With this approach, you keep all general setup code inside your subclass of GlobalSetup, and your GWT entry point stays dirt-simple.)

Once the static startup method in GlobalSetup is called, that's that! Dependency injection will boot up, your layout widget will be attached to the DOM and your app will go to the default place (or to whatever place is described in the URL fragment identifier in the browser's location bar).

Also: if you use external javascript libraries, you can ask the framework to fetch them and make sure they're loaded before the application actually starts up. There is also a facility for displaying "loading" messages and the like while external JS libraries load.

Places

Places in Pescador MVP have a few extra features that are not included in plain GWT Places. One of them is that you never have to make your own PlaceTokenizers. PescadorMVPPlaces store information in key-value pairs that are automatically serialized to and retrieved from the URL fragment identifier. They may also contain locale information and presentation text (for describing places in the UI).

PescadorMVPPlaces are passed around the Pescador MVP framework as interfaces, unlike standard GWT Places, which are implementations. However, PescadorMVPPlaces can always be converted to standard GWT Places if necessary.

Layout

Pescador MVP does not include a widget for laying out your app. Rather, it provides some interfaces that define behavior that your layout widget should implement. It does make some basic assumptions about your application's layout, namely that it has regions. However, it does not assume that the regions' dimensions will remain static, or that all regions must always be visible and associated with a view and an activity. Also, it makes allowances for UI elements that are not visually contained within a region (though such elements should be logically part of a view).

The central requirements for a Pescador MVP layout widget are: it must provide a set of interfaces that designate regions that it manages, and it must provide a container widget for each region it manages. In addition, it must provide an attach() method. Whatever code attaches your layout widget to the DOM should be placed in this method. It will be called just once when the framework starts up.

For a very simple example, see LayoutImpl.

Activities and Views Not Associated with a Place

It is possible to define activities and views that are not associated with a specific place. This can be useful, for example, if you have a tab panel in a region of your UI, and you want distinct activities and views for each tab. To accomplish this, your tab activities should implement PescadorMVPActivity (instead of PescadorMVPPlaceActivity ) and should extend PescadorMVPActivityBase (instead of PescadorMVPPlaceActivityBase ). You can set up a container activity and view (that are associated with a place) to manage the embedded activities and views. In such a scenario, your container activity will probably look like a much simplified version of GWT's ActivityManager.

Session

The Session component has some facilities for working with PescadorMVPLocales (which are slightly different from plain GWT locales). Plus, it provides a standardized way to store serializable session data. This component is also for moving about: you use Session.goTo(place) make the app go to a new place.

Extras

Pescador MVP includes a few extra facilities that are not properly part of an MVP framework, but that I've found quite useful.

Caching Command-Pattern Data Manager

Pescador MVP provides a data manager component for server requests following the command pattern, as implemented by gwt-dispatch. With this pattern, your requests are encapsulated in Action objects (for example, GetLatLonAction) and you get back Result objects (such as GetLatLonResult) that contain information provided by the server.

In addition to using the command pattern, Pescador MVP's data manager can cache the results of server calls. (The code for this is based on this blog post by David Chandler.) For results to be cached, the corresponding action must implement the tag interface CacheableAction. The maximum cache size is configurable (look at ActiveGlobalSetup to see how to set it.)

The data manager can handle both requests to your own server and requests to a third-party server (via JSONP). For requests to your own server, you must configure a servlet and register an ActionHandler as described in the gwt- dispatch documentation. For JSONP requests, create a JsonpActionHelper (such as GetLatLonActionHelperImpl ) and register it with the data manager (as shown in QueryComponentImpl).

Internal Links

The ...core.client.internallinks package has some utility classes for creating internal links (i.e., links to places within your application). These classes work well with PescadorMVPPlaces and produce native HTML hyperlinks that stay within your application when clicked on normally, and can also be control-clicked and right-clicked for native browser hyperlink actions.

Logger

This is just an easy-to-use, injectable a wrapper for GWT's logger. An example configuration is in examples/jsonp/src/main/resources/mx/org/pescadormvp/examples/jsonp/JSONPExample.gwt.xml .
